Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Exceptionally Short Telomeres in Filamentous Fungi and the RNA that Makes Them

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Telomeres are the very tips of chromosomes and have been studied intensely for their role in the replicative capacity of cancer and stem cells. In higher organisms, the telomeres of sperm and egg are longer than those of other cells, which have led to the hypothesis that lengthening of telomeres in germ cells is needed to reset the biological clock with every generation. Microbes that have a variety of different cell types provide a tractable means to address the question of telomere length in sex cells. Furthermore, such a group of microbes, the filamentous fungi, are among the species with the shortest telomeres known. One limitation of further studying these fungi is that one of the fundamental genes in telomere synthesis has yet to be identified. This gene encodes the telomerase RNA, which provides the template for synthesizing telomeres and is therefore crucial for life. Since telomerase RNA genes are highly divergent, with almost no sequence identity between organisms, they are much harder to identify than other genes in a new group of organisms. This project describes experiments to identify the first telomerase RNA in a group of microbes, the filamentous fungi. The experiments will take advantage of a long telomere repeat sequence, fortuitously present in a filamentous fungus of food microbiology, to devise a cross-disciplinary approach utilizing bioinformatics and molecular genetics. The length of the telomere repeat sequence means that the number of possible gene candidates will be reduced. Identifying the first telomerase RNA gene sequence within a diverse group of filamentous fungi will ultimately lead to a better understanding of telomere length regulation in sex cells and other cells, interactions between the telomerase RNA and essential proteins, and the evolution of this highly divergent gene.

Broader Impacts:
Although this project is focused on gaining a better understanding of the role of telomeres in cell development, there are many outcomes that will benefit the broader scientific community. First, undergraduates will develop new tools, such as a novel telomere diagnostic assay, providing scientists in other laboratories with an easier way to study telomere length. This assay will be disseminated to the scientific community in the form of a peer-reviewed publication with undergraduate coauthors. Second, undergraduates will collaborate with scientists from around the world. Finally, the results of the research extend well beyond the molecular scope of this laboratory. For example, identification of the telomerase RNA gene from a new group of organisms, the filamentous fungi, will provide data that is of interest to evolutionary biologists and other scientists. Thus, undergraduates who have had such a broad exposure to research will continue in their careers by making more educated decisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Telomeres, the outermost tips of linear chromosomes, are fascinating since these tiny regions are essential for the maintenance of the entire chromosome. In addition, their length has much to do with aging, stress, and cancer. The enzyme that synthesizes telomeres is intriguing, as it is one of the rare enzymes that is composed of protein and RNA. The RNA portion, called the telomerase RNA, plays an essential role in the templating of the telomeric DNA sequence. The gene encoding the telomerase RNA had been identified in some organisms, but was not identified in any filamentous fungi due to the huge diversity and sequence dissimilarity of the gene among known organisms. For example, although the genes were identified in yeast and a pond microbe (both single celled eukaryotes), the sequences were approximately 10-fold different in size and had virtually no sequence similarity. Thus, finding the gene in a filamentous fungus, or in most organisms, could not be accomplished by sequence similarity alone. Determining the sequence of the telomerase RNA in the filamentous fungi would provide the evolutionary connection, in addition to insight into structural certain mechanisms, between yeast and higher eukaryotes.

Undergraduates in my laboratory at Lake Forest College, a liberal arts college in the Midwest, identified a filamentous fungus, Aspergillus oryzae, which had a particularly long, repetitive telomeric DNA sequence. Due to the unusual length of this sequence, the predicted template sequence in the telomerase RNA also would be long, making it possible to use this sequence to hunt for the telomerase RNA gene. These undergraduates searched the genome of A. oryzae and ultimately found a sequence that was consistent with the telomerase RNA template sequence, among other key structural elements in the RNA. Students determined that the overall structure, not the sequence, of the telomerase RNAs from several filamentous fungi they identified is partly like that of yeasts, and partly like that of vertebrates. Thus, this telomerase RNA sequence fills a gap in our understanding of the evolution of the telomerase RNA.

An unusual feature of the Aspergilli, specifically Aspergillus nidulans, is that the overall telomere tract length is tightly regulated and exceptionally short— more so than any other group of eukaryotes. It was known that the telomere length of vegetative cells was maintained upon asexual sporulation, but it was not previously known whether the telomere length was altered during meiosis. In higher eukaryotes, such as mice and humans, the telomere length is often increased around meiotic events. My undergraduate students tested whether the telomeres were lengthened during and after the development of sexual spores that had gone through meiosis. However, to test such a telomere length in sexual spores, the students first needed to develop an approach that would determine the telomere length from a relatively low number of purified sexual spores. After such a novel approach was developed, which we termed Telomere-Anchored PCR, it was concluded that a surprisingly strict telomere length regulation exists in the sexual and asexual cell types of A. nidulans, as no length change was observed around meiosis. This suggests there might be a different mechanism in filamentous fungi to keep telomeres at a certain, specific and short length rather than be subjected to the longer and heterogeneous nature of other systems.

In conclusion, not only have many undergraduate students been trained to conduct research, but the field has developed due to their input. Students have designed and conducted new techniques that address large questions about the evolution and mechanism of telomere biology, and have published their work in quality journal articles so that other scientists may benefit.
